s.text: It was the first time a team with a female member had won the competition.
At Harvard, Zelon made history when her team won the Williston Competition, a contract-negotiating contest open to first-year law students at the school.
According to the attorneys who appear before her, Zelon succeeds in making everyone in her courtroom at ease.
According to the attorneys who appear before her, Zelon succeeds in making everyone in her courtroom at ease.

A member of the only student-run chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union in New York state, Zelon worked to resolve disputes between students and police officers to help protect the public's right to peaceful protest.
Shortly after earning her law degree, Zelon joined the American Bar Association's young lawyers division, where she served on and chaired several pro bono and public-service committees.

"What I try to do, so I can get enough trial time and so that the jurors are used in a way that makes sense to them, is start trial by 10:30 in the morning," Zelon said. "
A former president of the Los Angeles County Bar Association, Zelon, 49, says her 30 years of public-interest work have allowed her to understand the legal needs of the underprivileged.
Described by the attorneys who appear before her as a consummate professional, Zelon projects quiet determination, intense intellectual curiosity, confidence and thoughtfulness, on and off the bench.

During her career, she accomplished several things to improve legal funding for the poor, locally and nationwide.

In the late 1980s, she became chair of the American Bar Association's Standing Committee on Lawyers' Public Service Responsibility, the group responsible for the association's position on legal services for the poor.

During her 1995-96 term as president of the Los Angeles County Bar Association, Zelon appeared before Congress and successfully argued against its proposed elimination of the Public Service Corp., which grants funds to independent local programs that provide civil legal assistance to the poor.

"I didn't find out until I was standing in the great hall of the Supreme Court, surrounded by 300 people who were there, that the award had been named for me and was thereafter going to be given in my name.
"I affect people's lives one person at a time in this job, but sometimes, the effect can be pretty profound, and sometimes, it's not what you hoped it to be," she said.
